entry.title: Quantum supremacy: the gloves are off
entry.summary: Links:Google paper in NatureNew York Times articleIBM paper and blog post responding to Googleâs announcementBoaz Barakâs new post: âBoazâs inferior classical inferiority FAQâLipton and Reganâs postMy quantum supremacy interview with the BBC (featuring some of my fewest âuhmsâ and âahsâ ever!)NEW: My preprint with Sam Gunn, On the Classical Hardness of Spoofing Linear Cross-Entropy Benchmarking [â¦]

div.p:
Links:
Google paper in Nature
New York Times article
IBM paper and blog post responding to Googleâs announcement
Boaz Barakâs new post: âBoazâs inferior classical inferiority FAQâ
Lipton and Reganâs post
My quantum supremacy interview with the BBC (featuring some of my fewest âuhmsâ and âahsâ ever!)
NEW: My preprint with Sam Gunn, On the Classical Hardness of Spoofing Linear Cross-Entropy Benchmarking

When Googleâs quantum supremacy paper leaked a month agoânot through Googleâs error, but through NASAâsâI had a hard time figuring out how to cover the news here. I had to say something; on the other hand, I wanted to avoid any detailed technical analysis of the leaked paper, because I was acutely aware that my colleagues at Google were still barred by Natureâs embargo rules from publicly responding to anything I or others said. (I was also one of the reviewers for the Nature paper, which put additional obligations on me.)

I ended up with Scottâs Supreme Quantum Supremacy FAQ, which tried to toe this impossible line by âanswering general questions about quantum supremacy, and the consequences of its still-hypothetical achievement, in light of the leak.â It wasnât an ideal solutionâfor one thing, because while I still regard Googleâs sampling experiment as a historic milestone for our whole field, there are some technical issues, aspects that subsequent experiments (hopefully coming soon) will need to improve. Alas, the ground rules of my FAQ forced me to avoid such issues, which caused some readers to conclude mistakenly that I didnât think there were any.

Now, though, the Google paper has come out as Natureâs cover story, at the same time as there have been new technical developmentsâmost obviously, the paper from IBM (see also their blog post) saying that they could simulate the Google experiment in 2.5 days, rather than the 10,000 years that Google had estimated.

(Yesterday I was deluged by emails asking me âwhether Iâd seenâ IBMâs paper. As a science blogger, I try to respond to stuff pretty quickly when necessary, but I donâtâcanâtârespond in Twitter time.)
So now the gloves are off. No more embargo. Time to address the technical stuff under the hoodâwhich is the purpose of this post.

Iâm going to assume, from this point on, that you already understand the basics of sampling-based quantum supremacy experiments, and that I donât need to correct beginner-level misconceptions about what the term âquantum supremacyâ does and doesnât mean (no, it doesnât mean scalability, fault-tolerance, useful applications, breaking public-key crypto, etc. etc.). If this is not the case, you could start (e.g.) with my FAQ, or with John Preskillâs excellent Quanta commentary.
Without further ado:

p.strong: (1) So what about that IBM thing? Are random quantum circuits easy to simulate classically?

div.p: OK, so letâs carefully spell out what the IBM paper says. They argue that, by commandeering the full attention of Summit at Oak Ridge National Lab, the most powerful supercomputer that currently exists on Earthâone that fills the area of two basketball courts, and that (crucially) has 250 petabytes of hard disk spaceâone could just barely store the entire quantum state vector of Googleâs 53-qubit Sycamore chip in hard disk.Â And once one had done that, one could simulate the chip in ~2.5 days, more-or-less just by updating the entire state vector by brute force, rather than the 10,000 years that Google had estimated on the basis of my and Lijie Chenâs âSchrÃ¶dinger-Feynman algorithmâÂ (which can get by with less memory).

TheÂ IBM group understandably hasnât actually done this yetâeven though IBM set it up, the worldâs #1 supercomputer isnât just sitting around waiting for jobs! But I see little reason to doubt that their analysis is basically right. I donât know why the Google team didnât consider how such near-astronomical hard disk space would change their calculations; probably they wish they had.

I find this to be much, much better than IBMâs initial reaction to the Google leak, which was simply to dismiss the importance of quantum supremacy as a milestone. Designing better classical simulations is precisely how IBM and others should respond to Googleâs announcement, and how I said a month ago that I hoped they would respond. If we set aside the pass-the-popcorn PR war (or even if we donât), this is how science progresses.

But does IBMâs analysis mean that âquantum supremacyâ hasnât been achieved? No, it doesnâtâat least, not under any definition of âquantum supremacyâ that Iâve ever used. The Sycamore chip took about 3 minutes to generate the ~5 million samples that were needed to pass the âlinear cross-entropy benchmarkââthe statistical test that Google applies to the outputs of its device.

(Technical note added: Googleâs samples are extremely noisyâthe actual distribution being sampled from is something like 0.998U+0.002D, where U is the uniform distribution and D is the hard distribution that you want. What this means, in practice, is that you need to take a number of samples thatâs large compared to 1/0.0022, in order to extract a signal corresponding to D. But the good news is that Google can take that many samples in just a few minutes, since once the circuit has been loaded onto the chip, generating each sample takes only about 40 microseconds. And once youâve done this, what hardness results we have for passing the linear cross-entropy testâto be discussed later in this postâapply basically just as well as if youâd taken a single noiseless sample.)

Anyway, you might notice that three minutes versus 2.5 days is still a quantum speedup by a factor of 1200. But even more relevant, I think, is to compare the number of âelementary operations.â Letâs generously count a FLOP (floating-point operation) as the equivalent of a quantum gate. Then by my estimate, weâre comparing ~5Ã109 quantum gates against ~2Ã1020 FLOPsâa quantum speedup by a factor of ~40 billion.

For me, though, the broader point is that neither party hereâcertainly not IBMâdenies that the top-supercomputers-on-the-planet-level difficulty of classically simulating Googleâs 53-qubit programmable chip really is coming from the exponential character of the quantum states in that chip, and nothing else. Thatâs what makes this back-and-forth fundamentally different from the previous one between D-Wave and the people who sought to simulate its devices classically. The skeptics, like me, didnât much care what speedup over classical benchmarks there was or wasnât today: we cared about the increase in the speedup as D-Wave upgraded its hardware, and the trouble was that we never saw a convincing case that there would be one. Iâm a theoretical computer scientist, and this is what I believe: that after the constant factors have come and gone, what remains are asymptotic growth rates.

In the present case, while increasing the circuit depth wonât evade IBMâs âstore everything to hard diskâ strategy, increasing the number of qubits will. If Google, or someone else, upgraded from 53 to 55 qubits, that would apparently already be enough to exceed Summitâs 250-petabyte storage capacity. At 60 qubits, youâd need 33 Summits. At 70 qubits, enough Summits to fill a city â¦ you get the idea.

From the beginning, it was clear that quantum supremacy would not be a milestone like the moon landingâsomething thatâs achieved in a moment, and is then clear to everyone for all time. It would be more like eradicating measles: it could be achieved, then temporarily unachieved, then re-achieved. For by definition, quantum supremacy all about beating somethingânamely, classical computationâand the latter can, at least for a while, fight back.

As Boaz Barak put it to me, the current contest between IBM and Google is analogous to Kasparov versus Deep Blueâexcept with the world-historic irony that IBM is playing the role of Kasparov! In other words, Kasparov can put up a heroic struggle, during a âtransitional periodâ that lasts a year or two, but the fundamentals of the situation are that heâs toast. If Kasparov had narrowly beaten Deep Blue in 1997, rather than narrowly losing, the whole public narrative would likely have been different (âhumanity triumphs over computers after all!â). Yet as Kasparov himself well knew, the very fact that the contest was close meant that, either way, human dominance would soon end for good.
Let me leave the last word on this to friend-of-the-blog Greg Kuperberg, who graciously gave me permission to quote his comments about the IBM paper.

blockquote.p: Iâm not entirely sure how embarrassed Google should feel that they overlooked this.Â Â Iâm sure that they would have been happier to anticipate it, and happier still if they had put more qubits on their chip to defeat it.Â Â However, it doesnât change their real achievement.

I respect theÂ IBMÂ paper, even if the press along with it seems more grouchy than necessary.Â Â I tend to believe them that the Google team did not explore all avenues when they said that their 53 qubits arenât classically simulable.Â Â But if this is the best rebuttal, then you should still consider how much Google andÂ IBMÂ still agree on this as a proof-of-concept of QC.Â Â This is still quantum David vs classical Goliath, in the extreme.Â Â 53 qubits is in some ways still just 53 bits, only enhanced with quantum randomness.Â To answer those 53 qubits,Â IBMÂ would still needÂ entire days of computer time with the worldâs fastest supercomputer, a 200-petaflop machine with hundreds of thousands of processing cores and trillions of high-speed transistors.Â Â IfÂ we canÂ confirm that the Google chip actually meets spec, but we need this much computer power to do it, then to me thatâs about as convincing as a larger quantum supremacy demonstration that humanity can no longer confirm at all.
Honestly, Iâm happy to give both Google andÂ IBMÂ credit for helping the field of QC, even if it is the result of a strange dispute.

div.p: I should mention that, even before IBMâs announcement, Johnnie Gray, a postdoc at Imperial College, gave a talk (abstract here) at Caltechâs Institute for Quantum Information with a proposal for a different faster way to classically simulate quantum circuits like Googleâsâin this case, by doing tensor network contraction more cleverly. Unlike both IBMâs proposed brute-force simulation, and the SchrÃ¶dinger-Feynman algorithm that Google implemented, Grayâs algorithm (as far as we know now) would need to be repeated k times if you wanted k independent samples from the hard distribution. Partly because of this issue, Grayâs approach doesnât currently look competitive for simulating thousands or millions of samples, but weâll need to watch it and see what happens.

The discussion of IBMâs proposed simulation brings us to a curious aspect of the Google paperâone that was already apparent when Nature sent me the paper for review back in August. Namely, Google took its supremacy experiments well past the point where even they themselves knew how to verify the results, by any classical computation that they knew how to perform feasibly (say, in less than 10,000 years).

So you might reasonably ask: if they couldnât even verify the results, then how did they get to claim quantum speedups from those experiments? Well, they resorted to various gambits, which basically involved estimating the fidelity on quantum circuits that looked almost the same as the hard circuits, but happened to be easier to simulate classically, and then making the (totally plausible) assumption that that fidelity would be maintained on the hard circuits. Interestingly, they also cached their outputs and put them online (as part of the supplementary material to their Nature paper), in case it became feasible to verify them in the future.

Maybe you can now see where this is going. From Googleâs perspective, IBMâs rainstorm comes with a big silver lining. Namely, by using Summit, hopefully it will now be possible to verify Googleâs hardest (53-qubit and depth-20) sampling computations directly! This should provide an excellent test, since not even the Google group themselves wouldâve known how to cheat and bias the results had they wanted to.

This whole episode has demonstrated the importance, when doing a sampling-based quantum supremacy experiment, of going deep into the regime where you can no longer classically verify the outputs, as weird as that sounds. Namely, you need to leave yourself a margin, in the likely event that the classical algorithms improve!

Having said that, I donât mind revealing at this point that the lack of direct verification of the outputs, for the largest reported speedups, was my single biggest complaint when I reviewed Googleâs Nature submission. It was because of my review that they added a paragraph explicitly pointing out that they did do direct verification for a smaller quantum speedup:

blockquote.p: The largest circuits for which the fidelity can still be directly verified have 53 qubits and a simplified gate arrangement. Performing random circuit sampling on these at 0.8% fidelity takes one million cores 130 seconds, corresponding to a million-fold speedup of the quantum processor relative to a single core.

div.p: (An earlier version of this post misstated the numbers involved.)

p.strong: (3) The asymptotic hardness of spoofing Googleâs benchmark.

div.p: OK, but if Google thought that spoofing its test would take 10,000 years, using the best known classical algorithms running on the worldâs top supercomputers, and it turns out instead that it could probably be done in more like 2.5 days, then how much else couldâve been missed? Will we find out next that Googleâs benchmark can be classically spoofed in mere milliseconds?

Well, no one can rule that out, but we do have some reasons to think that itâs unlikelyâand crucially, that even if it turned out to be true, one would just have to add 10 or 20 or 30 more qubits to make it no longer true. (We canât be more definitive than that? Aye, such are the perils of life at a technological inflection pointâand of computational complexity itself.)

The key point to understand here is that we really are talking about simulating a random quantum circuit, with no particular structure whatsoever. While such problems might have a theoretically efficient classical algorithmâi.e., one that runs in time polynomial in the number of qubitsâIâd personally be much less surprised if you told me there was a polynomial-time classical algorithm for factoring. In the universe where amplitudes of random quantum circuits turn out to be efficiently computableâwell, you might as well just tell me that P=PSPACE and be done with it.

Crucially, if you look at IBMâs approach to simulating quantum circuits classically, and Johnnie Grayâs approach, and Googleâs approach, they could all be described as different flavors of âbrute force.â That is, they all use extremely clever tricks to parallelize, shave off constant factors, make the best use of available memory, etc., but none involves any deep new mathematical insight that could roust BPP and BQP and the other complexity gods from their heavenly slumber. More concretely, none of these approaches seem to have any hope of âbreaching the 2n barrier,â where n is the number of qubits in the quantum circuit to be simulated (assuming that the circuit depth is reasonably large). Mostly, theyâre just trying to get down to that barrier, while taking the maximum advantage of whatever storage and connectivity and parallelism are there.

Ah, but at the end of the day, we only believe that Googleâs Sycamore chip is solving a classically hard problem because of the statistical test that Google applies to its outputs: the so-called âLinear Cross-Entropy Benchmark,â which I described in Q3 of my FAQ. And even if we grant that calculating the output probabilities for a random quantum circuit is almost certainly classically hard, and sampling the output distribution of a random quantum circuit is almost certainly classically hardâstill, couldnât spoofing Googleâs benchmark be classically easy?

This last question is where complexity theory can contribute something to the story. A couple weeks ago, UT undergraduate Sam Gunn and I adapted the hardness analysis from my and Lijie Chenâs 2017 paper âComplexity-Theoretic Foundations of Quantum Supremacy Experiments,â to talk directly about the classical hardness of spoofing the Linear Cross-Entropy benchmark. Our short paper about this should be on the arXiv later this week (or early next week, given that there are no arXiv updates on Friday or Saturday nights) here it is.

Briefly, Sam and I show that if you had a sub-2n classical algorithm to spoof the Linear Cross-Entropy benchmark, then youâd also have a sub-2n classical algorithm that, given as input a random quantum circuit, could estimate a specific output probability (for example, that of the all-0 string) with variance at least slightly (say, Î©(2-3n)) better than that of the trivial estimator that just always guesses 2-n. Or in other words: we show that spoofing Googleâs benchmark is no easier than the general problem of nontrivially estimating amplitudes in random quantum circuits. Furthermore, this result automatically generalizes to the case of noisy circuits: all that the noise affects is the threshold for the Linear Cross-Entropy benchmark, and thus (indirectly) the number of samples one needs to take with the QC. Our result helps to explain why, indeed, neither IBM nor Johnnie Gray nor anyone else suggested any attack thatâs specific to Googleâs Linear Cross-Entropy benchmark: they all simply attack the general problem of calculating the final amplitudes.

p.strong: (4) Why use Linear Cross-Entropy at all?

div.p: In the comments of my FAQ, some people wondered why Google chose the Linear Cross-Entropy benchmark specificallyâespecially since theyâd used a different benchmark (multiplicative cross-entropy, which unlike the linear version actually is a cross-entropy) in their earlier papers. I asked John Martinis this question, and his answer was simply that linear cross-entropy had the lowest variance of any estimator they tried. Since I also like linear cross-entropyâit turns out, for example, to be convenient for the analysis of my certified randomness protocolâIâm 100% happy with their choice. Having said that, there are many other choices of benchmark that wouldâve also worked fine, and with roughly the same level of theoretical justification.

Another interesting detail from the Google paper is that, in their previous hardware, they could implement a particular 2-qubit gate called the Controlled-Z. For their quantum supremacy demonstration, on the other hand, they modified their hardware to implement a different 2-qubit gate called the iSWAP some weird combination of iSWAP and Controlled-Z; see the comments section for more. Now, this other gate has no known advantages over the Controlled-Z, for any applications like quantum simulation or Shorâs algorithm or Grover search. Why then did Google make the switch? Simply because, with certain classical simulation methods that theyâd been considering, the simulationâs running time grows like 4 to the power of the number of these other gates, but only like 2 to the power of the number of Controlled-Z gates! In other words, they made this engineering choice purely and entirely to make a classical simulation of their device sweat more. This seems totally fine and entirely within the rules to me. (Alas, this choice has no effect on a proposed simulation method like IBMâs.)

Over the past month, Shtetl-Optimized regular and noted quantum computing skeptic Gil Kalai has been posting one objection to the Google experiment after another on his blog. Unlike the IBM group and many of Googleâs other critics, Gil completely accepts the centrality of quantum supremacy as a goal. Indeed, heâs firmly predicted for years that quantum supremacy could never be achieved for fundamental reasonsâand he agrees that the Google result, if upheld, would refute his worldview. Gil also has no dispute with the exponential classical hardness of the problem that Google is solving.

Instead, Gilâif weâre talking not about âsteelmanningâ his beliefs, but about what he himself actually saidâhas taken the position that the Google experiment mustâve been done wrong and will need to be retracted. Heâs offered varying grounds for this. First he said that Google never computed the full histogram of probabilities with a smaller number of qubits (for which such an experiment is feasible), which would be an important sanity check. Except, it turns out they did do that, and itâs in their 2018 Science paper. Next he said that the experiment is invalid because the qubits have to be calibrated in a way that depends on the specific circuit to be applied. Except, this too turns out to be false: John Martinis explicitly confirmed for me that once the qubits are calibrated, you can run any circuit on them that you want. In summary, unlike the objections of the IBM group, so far Iâve found Gilâs objections to be devoid of scientific interest or merit.

Update #1: Alas, Iâll have limited availability today for answering comments, since weâll be grading the midterm exam for my Intro to Quantum Information Science course! Iâll try to handle the backlog tomorrow (Thursday).

Update #2: Aaannd â¦ timed to coincide with the Google paper, last night the group of Jianwei Pan and Chaoyang Lu put up a preprint on the arXiv reporting a BosonSampling experiment with 20 photons 14 photons observed out of 20 generated (the previous record had been 6 photons). At this stage of the quantum supremacy race, many had of course written off BosonSamplingâor said that its importance was mostly historical, in that it inspired Googleâs random circuit sampling effort.Â Iâm thrilled to see BosonSampling itself take such a leap; hopefully, this will eventually lead to a demonstration that BosonSampling was (is) a viable pathway to quantum supremacy as well.Â And right now, with fault-tolerance still having been demonstrated in zero platforms, we need all the viable pathways we can get.Â What an exciting day for the field.

category.term: Bell's Theorem? But a Flesh Wound!

entry.title: Newton MA votes on November 5: Residents vs. developers
entry.summary: Historically, progressive people have been understandably quite skeptical of big business, including developers. (I hesitated before using the word âprogressiveâ because the meaning is obscure, and there are several related words, like âliberalâ and so on. But the meaning on this post should be clear.) Recently, something shocking happened. Self-declared progressive people in Newton have [â¦]

div.p: Historically, progressive people have been understandably quite skeptical of big business, including developers. (I hesitated before using the word âprogressiveâ because the meaning is obscure, and there are several related words, like âliberalâ and so on. But the meaning on this post should be clear.)

Recently, something shocking happened. Self-declared progressive people in Newton have come to believe that the way to solve the worldâs problems is to slash regulations, rewrite zoning documents, chop down forests, and give a free hand to developers (not residents in Newton) to build whatever they want, no questions asked.Â (Wait, we are putting solar panels on the new roofs!)
As a consequence, there is now a heatedÂ battle in Newton, ward for ward, to try to protect our city against this well-funded and politically well-connected assault.

And we are not even discussing if we should build a mega complex as opposed to creating new green spaces and protected bike lanes, or improving public transportation, or finally having a gym and a swimming pool â all things that would improve our health and the quality of life.Â The discussion is just how big the mega complex should be.

p.a: This website describes the issues and tells you who to vote for.
This one too (endorsements have strong overlap with above but are not identical).

div.p: Â

div.p:
The Euler International Mathematical Institute in St.Petersburg is seeking
postdocs in Math, TCS, Mathematical and Theoretical Physics. St.Petersburg is the most beautiful city in the world and has multiple mathematical locations including Steklov Institute of Mathematics and Dept. of Mathematics and CS in St.Petersburg State Univ. The preference is given to applications sent before 11/30/19.

Website: http://math-cs.spbu.ru/en/news/news-2019-10-22/
Email: euler.postdoc@gmail.com
